data.title: A look back at Channing Frye's highlights as a Cleveland Cavalier: 33 photos
data.meta_description: A look back at Channing Frye's highlights as a Cleveland Cavalier: 33 photos
data.text:
Cleveland Cavaliers forward Channing Frye hammers down a dunk over Denver Nuggets center Nikola Jokic in the first half. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Channing Frye played his final NBA game Tuesday night in a Cavaliers jersey, a jersey in which he's happy to be retiring.

"I appreciate you guys," Frye said in a video to Cavs fans. "I wouldn't want to retire anywhere else. My heart is here in Cleveland. My championship is here in Cleveland. So I just want to say thank you. I embrace this community. You guys have embraced me. And I'm glad to be going out a Cav."

Frye was selected as the eighth overall pick in the 2005 NBA draft by the New York Knicks. He spent two years in the Big Apple before being traded to the Portland Trail Blazers in June 2007.

Frye spent time in Portland, Phoenix and Orlando before being traded to the Cavaliers in 2016, providing the Cavs with a much-needed big man who could spread the floor and hit outside shots.

In the trade for Frye, the Cavs sent center Anderson Varejao and a conditional first-round pick to the Blazers. Cleveland also traded guard Jared Cunningham in the deal, sending him to Orlando along with a second-round pick from Portland.

Frye had an immediate impact, helping the Cavs become a true team and playing a key role in the championship run. He was known in the locker room as the glue that kept the team cohesive.

"I'm humbled to be a part of this community. You changed my life. I'm a champion and so are you guys," Frye added.

Here's a look back at his short but positive impact on the Cleveland Cavaliers organization.

Cleveland Cavaliers forward Channing Frye warms up before the game against the Detroit Pistons, his first game at Quicken Loans Arena as a Cavalier. Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com

Frye protects the rim against Detroit Pistons forward Marcus Morris, who dishes the ball out in the first half. Frye finished his first game with one field goal, and limited minutes. Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com

Channing Frye gets a hug from LeBron James after Frye scored 27 points in a 121-108 Cavaliers win over Atlanta in the Eastern Conference playoffs May 6, 2016. (Gus Chan / The Plain Dealer)

Doing what he does best, Frye launches a 3-pointer against the Toronto Raptors in the first half of Game 2 of the Eastern Conference Finals Thursday, May 19, 2016. Frye finished the game with 10 points. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Cleveland Cavaliers fans cheer as their 2016 NBA Champion Cleveland Cavaliers return home to the IX Jet Center. The Cavaliers ended a 52-year Cleveland championship drought, defeating the Golden State Warriors in Game 7 of the NBA Finals. Frye did not play in the final three games of the Finals, but was a crucial part of keeping the team together. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com June 20, 2016.)

Frye is swarmed by media before the Cavaliers practice on May 27, 2016. (Gus Chan, The Plain Dealer)

LeBron James laughs with Frye during practice in preparation for Game 3 of the NBA Finals against the Golden State Warriors on June 7, 2016. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye deflects a shot from Warriors forward Draymond Green in the first half of Game 3 in 2016. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye and Golden State Warriors guard Klay Thompson fall out of bounds going after a loose ball in the second half of Game 3 in 2016. (Joshua Gunter)

Frye knocks the ball from the hands of Warriors forward Draymond Green in the first half during Game 4 of the NBA Finals on June 10, 2016 at Quicken Loans Arena. (John Kuntz, cleveland.com cleveland.com)

LeBron James and the jubilant Cavs family hoist the trophies in the NBA Finals Game 7 between the Cavaliers and the Golden State Warriors played in Oakland on Sunday, June 19, 2016. (Thomas Ondrey, The Plain Dealer)

Frye and head coach Tyronn Lue acknowledge the fans who packed the IX Center at Cleveland Hopkins Airport on the team's return home, June 20, 2016. (John Kuntz, cleveland.com)

Frye meets fans during the Cavaliers NBA Championship victory parade outside The Q, Wednesday, June 22, 2016. (Marvin Fong, The Plain Dealer)

Frye watches as Cleveland Browns great Jim Brown hands the Larry O'Brien Trophy to LeBron James at a rally to celebrate and honor the 2016 NBA Champion Cleveland Cavaliers on June 22, 2016. In Frye's speech from the stage, he spoke about his bond with this team before dropping the mic and sitting down. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

After having the Larry O'Brien Trophy handed to him by Jim Brown, James puts his arm around Brown at a rally to celebrate and honor the 2016 NBA Champion Cleveland Cavaliers. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye and the Cavs had the task of defending their title against a bolstered Golden State Warriors team. A task they couldn't achieve. The Cavs did defeat the Warriors on the Christmas day Finals rematch, however.

Warriors guard Stephen Curry is fouled by Frye on a breakaway to the basket with the defensive help of Cavaliers guard Kyrie Irving in the third quarter, Dec. 25, 2016, at Quicken Loans Arena. (John Kuntz, cleveland.com)

Frye can't believe a foul call against him against the San Antonio Spurs in the fourth quarter, January 21, 2017, at Quicken Loans Arena. (John Kuntz, cleveland.com)

Frye gets a shot rejected by New York Knicks forward Kristaps Porzingis during the 2017 season. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye waves to the Cavs employees and their families who came out to congratulate them on their season after arriving at Cleveland Hopkins International Airport, June 13, 2017, in Cleveland. (John Kuntz, cleveland.com)

Frye and Richard Jefferson laugh during training camp at Cleveland Clinic Courts in Independence. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye returns to a Cavs jersey as he poses for photos during Cavaliers Media Day 2018 at Cleveland Clinic Courts in Independence. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye says thank you to the Cavaliers fans before the start of his final NBA game on Tuesday night. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye fires a shot against the Charlotte Hornets in the second half of play Tuesday. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye acknowledges the crowd after hitting a 3-pointer against the Charlotte Hornets in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye gets a hug from Cavaliers center Tristan Thompson after subbing out for the final time in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye gets a hug from Larry Nance Jr. after subbing out for the final time in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye smiles after hitting a 3-pointer against the Charlotte Hornets in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye gets swarmed by his teammates after hitting a 3-pointer against the Charlotte Hornets in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye gets a hug from Kevin Love after subbing out for the final time in the second half of play. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye holds his children while watching a tribute video following his final game. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye hugs teammate Kevin Love after being given the game ball. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)

Frye kisses his daughter Margaux after a tribute video following his final game. (Joshua Gunter, cleveland.com)
